title: How to Give a Chinchilla a Dust Bath

steps.headline: Purchase the right type of dust.
steps.description: You can buy chinchilla bath dust, which replicates volcanic ash and sediment that they bathe with in the wild, at specialty pet stores or from online suppliers. You must purchase dust that is specifically for chinchilla dust baths. Do not use bath sands, as the grains are too coarse. A finely ground pumice is the best option. The dust you use should resemble volcanic ash, which is very fine and light. You can also buy lightly scented chinchilla dust, if you want a little something special.

steps.headline: Buy a proper dust house.
steps.description: Buy a dust house that is big enough for your chinchilla to roll around comfortably inside and that is heavy enough that it won't tip over. Fish bowls and plastic house-like containers are suitable choices for your chinchilla. The proper bathhouse will ensure that your chinchilla can comfortably and happily keep its coat shiny and clean. The right choice will also eliminate the majority of dust particles from exiting the house and ending up in the cage or surrounding areas. Buying a clear bathhouse will allow you to watch the entertaining wonder of a chinchilla taking this unique type of bath. Plastic houses will get scratched up overtime. If you plan on buying a clear house so that you can watch your chinchilla take its dust bath, a thick and sturdy glass house is a better option.

steps.headline: Read chinchilla pet product reviews.
steps.description: You want to ensure that you are purchasing the best type of dust and the best model house for your chinchilla. Purchase supplies from a reputable supplier. Reviews are a great way to exchange and receive information on different brands and products from someone other than the actual company or supplier. If you are buying your supplies from places like Amazon or eBay, you can easily access product ratings and reviews.

methods.name: Setting Up an Out-of-Cage Dust Bath

steps.headline: Put the bathhouse on a flat and non-elevated surface.
steps.description: Since your chinchilla will be vigorously rolling around, it is important that you set up the bathhouse in a safe location where there isn't a chance that it could fall off.

steps.headline: Pick a location where your chinchilla will feel at ease and secure.
steps.description: Your chinchilla’s dust bath should be a pleasurable and relaxed experience. Make sure larger pets, like dogs and cats, are not present as they can stress your chinchilla out and make it feel like it is in danger.

steps.headline: Open the container of chinchilla bath dust.
steps.description: The dust particles are very fine, so be careful when opening the container.

steps.headline: Fill the bathhouse with approximately 2 inches (5.1 cm) of dust.
steps.description: Your chinchilla needs the dust to be deep enough that it can roll around and coat its coat generously. For larger chinchillas, you may need to add 3 to 4 inches (7.6 to 10 cm) of dust. A little too much is better than not enough.

steps.headline: Remove your chinchilla from its cage.
steps.description: Gently scoop your chinchilla up with both hands from underneath. Be careful not to grab it by the tip of the tail, as it can easily snap off. Once you have scooped up your chinchilla, hold it gently but firmly against your chest. Chinchilla don’t like to have their legs dangling. Make sure you have a firm hold on your chinchilla while transporting it to its bathhouse, as they are very quick to move and can easily escape your grasp if not held properly.

steps.headline: Place your chinchilla inside of the bathhouse.
steps.description: Slowly release your hold as you place it in its secure bathhouse. At this point, you can just sit back and enjoy the marvel of the chinchilla dust bath. Just keep an eye on your chinchilla so that you know when it is done bathing.

steps.headline: Remove the chinchilla from its bathhouse.
steps.description: When your chinchilla is finished bathing, it will start exiting the bathhouse. You want to make sure that you are there for this in order to avoid an unnoticed escape. Pick up your chinchilla with both hands and from underneath its body and transport it back to its cage. Chinchillas are very exploratory, which can be an issue if yours escapes while being unsupervised during its dust bath. A chinchilla can find itself in a dangerous situation if left alone in the open. For example, they are known to chew through electrical wires, scavenge and ingest something harmful, or encounter a predatory animal. Keep an eye on your little furry friend.

steps.headline: Return your chinchilla to its cage.
steps.description: Slowly lower your chinchilla back into its enclosure and release your gentle grasp. Close and secure the cage.

steps.headline: Vacuum or wipe down the area surrounding the bathhouse.
steps.description: Loose dust particles can be easily picked up with a damp cloth or hand held vacuum cleaner.

steps.headline: Give your chinchilla the opportunity for a bath one to three times a week.
steps.description: Chinchillas need to take a dust bath one to three times a week in order to remove excess oils from their skin and coat.

methods.name: Setting Up an In-Cage Dust Bath

steps.headline: Prepare the bathhouse outside of the cage.
steps.description: Fill the house with approximately two inches of chinchilla bath dust. You can reuse the dust if it is not showing signs of clumping and it hasn’t been soiled. You should, however, change the dust once a week.

steps.headline: Clear a spot inside of the cage.
steps.description: Find a flat and non-elevated area inside of the cage. You may need to move things around in order to make room for the bathhouse.

steps.headline: Place the bathhouse in the designated area inside of the cage.
steps.description: Close the cage. Your chinchilla may find this method and location much more peaceful than moving out of the cage for an out-of-cage dust bath.

steps.headline: Give your chinchilla time to take its dust bath.
steps.description: Your chinchilla will find its way to the bathhouse when it is ready. Obviously, there is no chance of escape as with an out-of-cage bath, but you will surely enjoy just watching. A chinchilla bath typically lasts between ten and fifteen minutes.

steps.headline: Remove the bathhouse from cage.
steps.description: Your chinchilla will exit the bathhouse when he or she is finished bathing. You should remove the bathhouse as soon as you notice that bath time is over in order to avoid the bathhouse being used a toilet.

steps.headline: Wipe down any visible dust particles inside of the cage.
steps.description: Keep your chinchilla’s home tidy. Use an unscented, pet-safe disinfectant and clean clothe or paper towel to clean any areas that have been dusted. You should also clean your chinchilla’s entire habitat once a week.

steps.headline: Prepare a dust bath one to three times a week.
steps.description: If your chinchilla is feeling bath deprived, you will notice that it will take a much longer bath. This is a good indication that you should offer your chinchilla more frequent opportunities to take a dust bath. If you notice that your chinchilla’s coat looks very dry and flaky, decrease the amount of baths per week. Increase the amount of baths per week if the weather is very humid.

If you are buying your supplies from places like Amazon or eBay, you can easily access product ratings and reviews. Since your chinchilla will be vigorously rolling around, it is important that you set up the bathhouse in a safe location where there isn't a chance that it could fall off. Pick a location where your chinchilla will feel at ease and secure. Your chinchilla’s dust bath should be a pleasurable and relaxed experience. Make sure larger pets, like dogs and cats, are not present as they can stress your chinchilla out and make it feel like it is in danger. Open the container of chinchilla bath dust. The dust particles are very fine, so be careful when opening the container. Fill the bathhouse with approximately 2 inches (5.1 cm) of dust. Your chinchilla needs the dust to be deep enough that it can roll around and coat its coat generously. For larger chinchillas, you may need to add 3 to 4 inches (7.6 to 10 cm) of dust. A little too much is better than not enough. Remove your chinchilla from its cage. Gently scoop your chinchilla up with both hands from underneath. Be careful not to grab it by the tip of the tail, as it can easily snap off. Once you have scooped up your chinchilla, hold it gently but firmly against your chest. Chinchilla don’t like to have their legs dangling. Make sure you have a firm hold on your chinchilla while transporting it to its bathhouse, as they are very quick to move and can easily escape your grasp if not held properly. Place your chinchilla inside of the bathhouse. Slowly release your hold as you place it in its secure bathhouse. At this point, you can just sit back and enjoy the marvel of the chinchilla dust bath. Just keep an eye on your chinchilla so that you know when it is done bathing. Remove the chinchilla from its bathhouse. When your chinchilla is finished bathing, it will start exiting the bathhouse. You want to make sure that you are there for this in order to avoid an unnoticed escape. Pick up your chinchilla with both hands and from underneath its body and transport it back to its cage. Chinchillas are very exploratory, which can be an issue if yours escapes while being unsupervised during its dust bath. A chinchilla can find itself in a dangerous situation if left alone in the open. For example, they are known to chew through electrical wires, scavenge and ingest something harmful, or encounter a predatory animal. Keep an eye on your little furry friend. Return your chinchilla to its cage. Slowly lower your chinchilla back into its enclosure and release your gentle grasp. Close and secure the cage. Vacuum or wipe down the area surrounding the bathhouse. Loose dust particles can be easily picked up with a damp cloth or hand held vacuum cleaner. Give your chinchilla the opportunity for a bath one to three times a week. Chinchillas need to take a dust bath one to three times a week in order to remove excess oils from their skin and coat. Setting Up an In-Cage Dust Bath Prepare the bathhouse outside of the cage. Fill the house with approximately two inches of chinchilla bath dust. You can reuse the dust if it is not showing signs of clumping and it hasn’t been soiled. You should, however, change the dust once a week. Clear a spot inside of the cage. Find a flat and non-elevated area inside of the cage. You may need to move things around in order to make room for the bathhouse. Place the bathhouse in the designated area inside of the cage. Close the cage. Your chinchilla may find this method and location much more peaceful than moving out of the cage for an out-of-cage dust bath. Give your chinchilla time to take its dust bath. Your chinchilla will find its way to the bathhouse when it is ready. Obviously, there is no chance of escape as with an out-of-cage bath, but you will surely enjoy just watching. A chinchilla bath typically lasts between ten and fifteen minutes. Remove the bathhouse from cage. Your chinchilla will exit the bathhouse when he or she is finished bathing. You should remove the bathhouse as soon as you notice that bath time is over in order to avoid the bathhouse being used a toilet. Wipe down any visible dust particles inside of the cage. Keep your chinchilla’s home tidy. Use an unscented, pet-safe disinfectant and clean clothe or paper towel to clean any areas that have been dusted. You should also clean your chinchilla’s entire habitat once a week. Prepare a dust bath one to three times a week. If your chinchilla is feeling bath deprived, you will notice that it will take a much longer bath. This is a good indication that you should offer your chinchilla more frequent opportunities to take a dust bath. If you notice that your chinchilla’s coat looks very dry and flaky, decrease the amount of baths per week. Increase the amount of baths per week if the weather is very humid.

You must purchase dust that is specifically for chinchilla dust baths.
Do not use bath sands, as the grains are too coarse.
A finely ground pumice is the best option.
The dust you use should resemble volcanic ash, which is very fine and light.
You can also buy lightly scented chinchilla dust, if you want a little something special.
Buy a proper dust house.

Fish bowls and plastic house-like containers are suitable choices for your chinchilla.

Plastic houses will get scratched up overtime.

Make sure larger pets, like dogs and cats, are not present as they can stress your chinchilla out and make it feel like it is in danger.

The dust particles are very fine, so be careful when opening the container.
Fill the bathhouse with approximately 2 inches (5.1 cm) of dust.
Your chinchilla needs the dust to be deep enough that it can roll around and coat its coat generously.
For larger chinchillas, you may need to add 3 to 4 inches (7.6 to 10 cm) of dust.
A little too much is better than not enough.

Gently scoop your chinchilla up with both hands from underneath.
Be careful not to grab it by the tip of the tail, as it can easily snap off.
Once you have scooped up your chinchilla, hold it gently but firmly against your chest.
Chinchilla don’t like to have their legs dangling.
Make sure you have a firm hold on your chinchilla while transporting it to its bathhouse, as they are very quick to move and can easily escape your grasp if not held properly.

Slowly release your hold as you place it in its secure bathhouse.
At this point, you can just sit back and enjoy the marvel of the chinchilla dust bath.
Just keep an eye on your chinchilla so that you know when it is done bathing.

For example, they are known to chew through electrical wires, scavenge and ingest something harmful, or encounter a predatory animal.
Keep an eye on your little furry friend.

Slowly lower your chinchilla back into its enclosure and release your gentle grasp.

Setting Up an In-Cage Dust Bath Prepare the bathhouse outside of the cage.
Fill the house with approximately two inches of chinchilla bath dust.
You can reuse the dust if it is not showing signs of clumping and it hasn’t been soiled.
You should, however, change the dust once a week.

Use an unscented, pet-safe disinfectant and clean clothe or paper towel to clean any areas that have been dusted.
You should also clean your chinchilla’s entire habitat once a week.
Prepare a dust bath one to three times a week.
If your chinchilla is feeling bath deprived, you will notice that it will take a much longer bath.
